Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_community_planning_program
Datasets.Description: The Regional Plan establishes long-range, region-wide planning policies outlining where, when, and how future growth and development should take place. The Regional Plan also establishes the Community Planning Program, which will reorganize HRM’s current planning framework into three geographies, the Regional Centre, Suburban Area and  Rural Area. This dataset serves to reference document for these three Regional Plan Areas, providing users spatial and temporal dimensions to support plan review processes and inform decision makers.
Datasets.Summary: The polygon features within this dataset identify the specific Regional Plan Area applicable to distinct areas within the Municipality. The dataset also serves as an reference source for POSSE, providing information and context for planning and permitting reviews.
Datasets.Purpose: The polygon features within this dataset identify the specific Regional Plan Area applicable to distinct areas within the Municipality. The dataset also serves as an reference source for POSSE, providing information and context for planning and permitting reviews.
Datasets.Tags: Regional Plan, Centre Plan, Suburban Plan, Rural Plan, Regional Plan Boundaries

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_electoral_district_ns
Datasets.Description: The electoral district names and boundaries are based on amendments to the House of Assembly Act passed on December 6, 2012 (Chapter 61 of the Acts of 2012) and passed on May 10, 2013 (Chapters 10 and 19 to 23 of the Acts of 2013). The electoral district boundaries take effect on the dissolution of the 61st House of Assembly for the 39th General Election since Confederation.
Datasets.Summary: Digital representation of electoral geography for Nova Scotia, used to support the electoral process.

The user is authorized to use the geographic data solely for its own internal operation with respect to its specific needs. Reproduction or redistribution of copyrighted geographic data outside of user's organization or entity is expressly forbidden unless prior permission is granted by ENS.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_fire_response_zone
Datasets.Description: Administrative boundaries for Fire
Datasets.Summary: This polygon feature class defines the CAD dispatch boundaries for fire incidents. Each zone in the CAD system determines which fire stations and apparatus type are sent to addresses based on the call type. The FDMID field contains the numerical zone number with the zone configuration type (A, B, C, D, E & H).  Numerous zones fall outside of HRM where we provide dispatching for adjacent municipalities.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_gflum_regplan
Datasets.Description: There are seven general land us designations which form the framework for achieving the growth management strategy of the Halifax Regional Plan. Urban Settlement, Urban Reserve, Rural Settlement, Rural Commuter, Rural Resource, Agriculturaland Open Space and Natural Resource. The centres have been defined and strategically located where services such as transit, wastewater and water can be economically and efficiently provided. One quarter of the predicted growth will occur within the Regional Centre, and half will be directed towards suburban areas. Policies regarding management of large subdivision development, island development, and the provision of incentives for redevelopment of abandoned and underutilised properties, are additional growth management mechanisms outlined in this Plan.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_growth_control_area
Datasets.Description: Physical boundary of the Beaver Bank / Hammonds Plains Growth Control Areas
Datasets.Summary: Until a substantive change is made in the infrastructure capacity within the Hammonds Plains and Beaver Bank areas, due to the safety concerns stated in section 4.1.1.4, it is appropriate to limit all further residential subdivision activity involving new public roads in these areas. As provided for by the Municipal Government Act, existing plans of residential subdivision, at the tentative or final plan of subdivision stage on or before the effective date of this Plan, shall be permitted to proceed through to completion.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_transportation_analysis_zone
Datasets.Description: This polygon feature class contains Transportation Analysis Zones covering the HRM and Joint Regional Transportation Agency (JRTA) area. Transportation Analysis Zones are geographical areas utilized in transportation planning to model and analyze travel behavior, patterns, and infrastructure needs. The layer was created by Transportation Planning in January 2023.
Datasets.Summary: TAZs play a pivotal role in transportation planning and analysis, offering a spatial framework for understanding travel demand, evaluating transportation systems, and shaping policy and investment decisions aimed at improving mobility, accessibility, and sustainability. This dataset serves as a reference layer for future studies and is utilized in various internal web applications for symbolization purposes. These geographies form the foundation for HRM's travel demand model.
Datasets.Purpose: TAZs play a pivotal role in transportation planning and analysis, offering a spatial framework for understanding travel demand, evaluating transportation systems, and shaping policy and investment decisions aimed at improving mobility, accessibility, and sustainability. This dataset serves as a reference layer for future studies and is utilized in various internal web applications for symbolization purposes. These geographies form the foundation for HRM's travel demand model.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.AST_green_cart
Datasets.Description:
Points representing green carts used for organic waste collection.

All the historical green cart files and monthly updates from the live Hansen records have been combined into one file geographically referenced to civic addresses (CIVID). Each cart record is represented by a point and reflect the history of deliveries, repairs and removals. At a particular civic address there may be no cart record (not a residential property), one or many cart records. Certain records have been flagged as being of known suspicious quality.
Datasets.Summary: This file was created at the request of Solid Waste to help them manage the green cart assets. The intention is to allow Solid Waste to validate the appropriateness of the records before the cart data is make public. There are error flags associated with certain records to enable Solid Waste to identify the records that are definitely suspicious in quality. When it is decided to publish this data to a wider audience a thorough evaluation of the best distribution method will be made.
Datasets.Purpose: This file was created at the request of Solid Waste to help them manage the green cart assets. When it is decided to publish this data to a wider audience a thorough evaluation of the best distribution method will be made.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.AST_pavement_rating
Datasets.Description: Linear representation of HRM owned or maintained street inventory and condition rating data as collected by the Infrastructure Management Services section of TPW.
Datasets.Summary: Infrastructure Management Services is a section of Design and Construction that manages the street surface infrastructure of T&PW. We maintain an inventory of HRM owned or maintained streets, and inspect these streets using a Pavement Condition Management System. These ratings are used to develop capital projects and provide network level analysis on these assets. The computer program enables us to see how these various asset conditions change over time depending on the amount of money allocated in the Capital Budget. We can also run various computer simulations on the various networks using different budget and rehabilitation scenarios to determine how we can get the most assets rehabilitated for the least amount of money.
Datasets.Purpose: Infrastructure Management Services is a section of Design and Construction that manages the street surface infrastructure of T&PW. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_census_tract_2016
Datasets.Description: This dataset is a compilation of Statistics Canada Census Tracts with associated population data from the 2016 Census. According to Stats Can, Census tracts (CTs) are small, relatively stable geographic areas that usually have a population of less than 10,000 persons, based on data from the previous Census of Population Program. They are located in census metropolitan areas and in census agglomerations that had a core population of 50,000 or more in the previous census.
Datasets.Summary: This dataset was created for statistical purposes and to perform population calculations.  It can be used as a base for all Statistics Canada tabular data that is at the Census Tract level.

Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for 5 year age ranges.  According to Statistics Canada, 'Age' refers to the age of a person (or subject) of interest at last birthday (or relative to a specified, well-defined reference date). The census was conducted on May 10, 2016 therefore as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 10, 2018.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_hh_age
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Total Household Population by Age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for total household population by age. According to Statistics Canada, Household refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_hh_maintainer
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Households by Maintainer Age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for households by maintainer age.  According the Statistics Canada, Household Maintainer refers to whether or not a person residing in the household is responsible for paying the rent, or the mortgage, or the taxes, or the electricity or other services or utilities. Where a number of people may contribute to the payments, more than one person in the household may be identified as a household maintainer. If no person in the household is identified as making such payments, the reference person is identified by default. Household refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_hh_size
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Households by Size of Household variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for households by size of household. According to Statistics Canada, 'Household size' refers to the number of persons in a private household. 'Private household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The household universe is divided into two sub-universes on the basis of whether the household is occupying a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The latter is a private household. For census purposes, households are classified into three groups: private households, collective households and households outside Canada. Unless otherwise specified, all data in census products are for private households only.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_hh_type
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Households by Household Type variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for households by holdhold type. According Statistics Canada, 'Household type' refers to the differentiation of households on the basis of whether they are census family households or non-census-family households. Census family households are those that contain at least one census family. Non-census-family households are either one person living alone or a group of two or more persons who live together but do not constitute a census family. Census family households may be differentiated based on the presence of additional persons (that is, persons not in a census family).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_hs_condo_stat
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Occupied Private Dwellings by Condo Status, Tenure & Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for occupied private dwellings by condo status, tenure and structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Condominium status' refers to whether the private dwelling is part of a condominium development. A condominium is a residential complex in which dwellings are owned individually while land and common elements are held in joint ownership with others. 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Tenure' refers to whether the household owns or rents their private dwelling. The private dwelling may be situated on rented or leased land or be part of a condominium. A household is considered to own their dwelling if some member of the household owns the dwelling even if it is not fully paid for, for example if there is a mortgage or some other claim on it. A household is considered to rent their dwelling if no member of the household owns the dwelling. A household is considered to rent that dwelling even if the dwelling is provided without cash rent or at a reduced rent, or if the dwelling is part of a cooperative.

Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Occupied Private Dwellings by Period of Construction variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for occupied private dwellings by period of construction. According to Statistics Canada, 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Period of construction' refers to the period in time during which the building or dwelling was originally constructed. This refers to the period in which the building was completed, not the time of any later remodelling, additions or conversions.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_hs_struct_type
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Occupied Private Dwellings by Structure Type variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for occupied private dwellings by structure type. According to Statistics Canada, 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Structural type' refers to the structural characteristics and/or dwelling configuration, that is, whether the dwelling is a single-detached house, an apartment in a high-rise building, a row house, a mobile home, etc.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_inc_constant
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Housholds by Income (Constant Year) variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for households by income (constant year - 2015). According Statistics Canada, 'constant dollar' refers to dollars of several years expressed in terms of their value ("purchasing power") in a single year, called the base year. This type of adjustment is done to eliminate the impact of widespread price changes. 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_job_industry
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Household Population 15 Years of Over by Industry variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for 5 household population 15 years or over by industry.  According to Statistics Canada, 'Industry' refers to a generally homogeneous group of economic producing units, primarily engaged in a specific set of activities. An activity is a particular method of combining goods and services inputs, labour and capital to produce one or more goods and/or services (products). In most cases, the activities that define an industry are homogeneous with respect to the production processes used (based on the North American Industry Classification System [NAICS] 2012).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_job_labour
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Household Population 15 Years or Over by Labour Force Activity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2018. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2018. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_job_occupation
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 household population 15 years or over by occupation variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population15 years or over by occupation.  According Statistics Canada, 'Occupation' refers to the kind of work performed in a job, a job being all the tasks carried out by a particular worker to complete his or her duties. An occupation is a set of jobs that are sufficiently similar in work performed. Kind of work is described in terms of tasks, duties and responsibilities, often including factors such as materials processed or used, the industrial processes used, the equipment used, and the products or services provided. Occupations are generally homogeneous with respect to skill type and skill level. Occupation applies to the contribution of labour to that part of economic activity that is within the production boundary defined for the System of National Accounts. (based on the National Occupational Classification [NOC] 2016).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_li_aboriginal
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Household Population by Aboriginal Identity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population by aboriginal identity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Aboriginal identity' refers to whether the person identified with the Aboriginal peoples of Canada. This includes those who are First Nations (North American Indian), Métis or Inuk (Inuit) and/or those who are Registered or Treaty Indians (that is, registered under the Indian Act of Canada), and/or those who have membership in a First Nation or Indian band. Aboriginal peoples of Canada are defined in the Constitution Act, 1982, Section 35 (2) as including the Indian, Inuit and Métis peoples of Canada.

According to Statistics Canada, 'Immigrant' refers to a person who is, or who has ever been, a landed immigrant or permanent resident. Such a person has been granted the right to live in Canada permanently by immigration authorities. Immigrants who have obtained Canadian citizenship by naturalization are included in this group.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_li_lang_official
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Household Population by Knowledge of Official Language variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population by knowledge of official languages. According to Statistics Canada, 'Knowledge of official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in English only, French only, in both or in neither language. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. 'Knowledge of non-official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in a language other than English or French. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. The number of languages that can be reported may vary between surveys, depending on the objectives of the survey.

Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population by 5 year mobility. According to Statistics Canada, 'Mobility status, five years' refers to the status of a person with regard to the place of residence on the reference day in relation to the place of residence on the same date five years earlier.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_li_mthr_tongue
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Household Population by Mother Tongue variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population by mother tongue. According to Statistics Canada, 'Mother tongue' refers to the first language learned at home in childhood and still understood by the person at the time the data was collected. If the person no longer understands the first language learned, the mother tongue is the second language learned. For a person who learned two languages at the same time in early childhood, the mother tongue is the language this person spoke most often at home before starting school. The person has two mother tongues only if the two languages were used equally often and are still understood by the person. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, the mother tongue is the language spoken most often to this child at home. The child has two mother tongues only if both languages are spoken equally often so that the child learns both languages at the same time.

Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Household Population by Total Immigrants & Place of Birth variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population by total immigrants and place of birth. According to Statistics Canada, 'Place of birth' refers to the name of the geographic location where the person was born. The geographic location is specified according to geographic boundaries current at the time of data collection, not the geographic boundaries at the time of birth.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_li_vis_minority
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Household Population by Visible Minority Status variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for household population by visible minority status.  According to Statistics Canada, 'Visible minority' refers to whether a person belongs to a visible minority group as defined by the Employment Equity Act and, if so, the visible minority group to which the person belongs. The Employment Equity Act defines visible minorities as "persons, other than Aboriginal peoples, who are non-Caucasian in race or non-white in colour". The visible minority population consists mainly of the following groups: South Asian, Chinese, Black, Filipino, Latin American, Arab, Southeast Asian, West Asian, Korean and Japanese.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_ms_famstr_cen
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Census Families by Family Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for census families by family structure.  According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2018_ms_famstr_hh
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2018 Census Family Households by Family Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for census family households by family structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children. 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2018 census data for PRIZM5 household counts. Environics PRIZM classifies Canada's neighbourhoods into 68 unique lifestyle types by integrating geographic, demographic and psychographic data. According to Statistics Canada, 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 population by age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for 5 year age ranges. According to Statistics Canada, 'Age' refers to the age of a person (or subject) of interest at last birthday (or relative to a specified, well-defined reference date). The census was conducted on May 10, 2016 therefore as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 10, 2019.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_hh_children
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Total Children at Home by Age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for total children at home by age. According to Statistics Canada, Household refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_hh_citizen
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Household Population by Citizen Age and Household Population by Non_Citizen Age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for total household population by citizen age. The 2019 dataset is slightly different than the 2018 as the 2019 data is generalized into age groups instead of individual ages. According to Statistics Canada, Household refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household. Citizen refers to persons who are citizens of Canada only and persons who are citizens of Canada and at least one other country.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_hh_maintainer
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Households by Maintainer Age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for households by maintainer age. According the Statistics Canada, Household Maintainer refers to whether or not a person residing in the household is responsible for paying the rent, or the mortgage, or the taxes, or the electricity or other services or utilities. Where a number of people may contribute to the payments, more than one person in the household may be identified as a household maintainer. If no person in the household is identified as making such payments, the reference person is identified by default. Household refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_hh_size
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Households by Size of Household variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for households by size of household. According to Statistics Canada, 'Household size' refers to the number of persons in a private household. 'Private household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The household universe is divided into two sub-universes on the basis of whether the household is occupying a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The latter is a private household. For census purposes, households are classified into three groups: private households, collective households and households outside Canada. Unless otherwise specified, all data in census products are for private households only.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_hh_type
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Households by Household Type variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for households by holdhold type. According Statistics Canada, 'Household type' refers to the differentiation of households on the basis of whether they are census family households or non-census-family households. Census family households are those that contain at least one census family. Non-census-family households are either one person living alone or a group of two or more persons who live together but do not constitute a census family. Census family households may be differentiated based on the presence of additional persons (that is, persons not in a census family).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_hs_condo_stat
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Occupied Private Dwellings by Condo Status, Tenure & Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for occupied private dwellings by condo status, tenure and structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Condominium status' refers to whether the private dwelling is part of a condominium development. A condominium is a residential complex in which dwellings are owned individually while land and common elements are held in joint ownership with others. 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Tenure' refers to whether the household owns or rents their private dwelling. The private dwelling may be situated on rented or leased land or be part of a condominium. A household is considered to own their dwelling if some member of the household owns the dwelling even if it is not fully paid for, for example if there is a mortgage or some other claim on it. A household is considered to rent their dwelling if no member of the household owns the dwelling. A household is considered to rent that dwelling even if the dwelling is provided without cash rent or at a reduced rent, or if the dwelling is part of a cooperative.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_hs_construct
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Occupied Private Dwellings by Period of Construction variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for occupied private dwellings by period of construction. According to Statistics Canada, 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Period of construction' refers to the period in time during which the building or dwelling was originally constructed. This refers to the period in which the building was completed, not the time of any later remodelling, additions or conversions.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_inc_constant
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Housholds by Income (Constant Year) variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for households by income (constant year - 2015). According Statistics Canada, 'constant dollar' refers to dollars of several years expressed in terms of their value ("purchasing power") in a single year, called the base year. This type of adjustment is done to eliminate the impact of widespread price changes. 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_job_industry
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Household Population 15 Years of Over by Industry variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for 5 household population 15 years or over by industry. According to Statistics Canada, 'Industry' refers to a generally homogeneous group of economic producing units, primarily engaged in a specific set of activities. An activity is a particular method of combining goods and services inputs, labour and capital to produce one or more goods and/or services (products). In most cases, the activities that define an industry are homogeneous with respect to the production processes used (based on the North American Industry Classification System [NAICS] 2012).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_job_labour
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Household Population 15 Years or Over by Labour Force Activity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2019. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2019. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_job_occupation
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 household population 15 years or over by occupation variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for household population15 years or over by occupation. According Statistics Canada, 'Occupation' refers to the kind of work performed in a job, a job being all the tasks carried out by a particular worker to complete his or her duties. An occupation is a set of jobs that are sufficiently similar in work performed. Kind of work is described in terms of tasks, duties and responsibilities, often including factors such as materials processed or used, the industrial processes used, the equipment used, and the products or services provided. Occupations are generally homogeneous with respect to skill type and skill level. Occupation applies to the contribution of labour to that part of economic activity that is within the production boundary defined for the System of National Accounts. (based on the National Occupational Classification [NOC] 2016).

Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Household Population by Aboriginal Identity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for household population by aboriginal identity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Aboriginal identity' refers to whether the person identified with the Aboriginal peoples of Canada. This includes those who are First Nations (North American Indian), Métis or Inuk (Inuit) and/or those who are Registered or Treaty Indians (that is, registered under the Indian Act of Canada), and/or those who have membership in a First Nation or Indian band. Aboriginal peoples of Canada are defined in the Constitution Act, 1982, Section 35 (2) as including the Indian, Inuit and Métis peoples of Canada.

Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Household Population by Knowledge of Official Language variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for household population by knowledge of official languages. According to Statistics Canada, 'Knowledge of official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in English only, French only, in both or in neither language. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. 'Knowledge of non-official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in a language other than English or French. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. The number of languages that can be reported may vary between surveys, depending on the objectives of the survey.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_li_mthr_tongue
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Household Population by Mother Tongue variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for household population by mother tongue. According to Statistics Canada, 'Mother tongue' refers to the first language learned at home in childhood and still understood by the person at the time the data was collected. If the person no longer understands the first language learned, the mother tongue is the second language learned. For a person who learned two languages at the same time in early childhood, the mother tongue is the language this person spoke most often at home before starting school. The person has two mother tongues only if the two languages were used equally often and are still understood by the person. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, the mother tongue is the language spoken most often to this child at home. The child has two mother tongues only if both languages are spoken equally often so that the child learns both languages at the same time.

Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Household Population by Visible Minority Status variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for household population by visible minority status. According to Statistics Canada, 'Visible minority' refers to whether a person belongs to a visible minority group as defined by the Employment Equity Act and, if so, the visible minority group to which the person belongs. The Employment Equity Act defines visible minorities as "persons, other than Aboriginal peoples, who are non-Caucasian in race or non-white in colour". The visible minority population consists mainly of the following groups: South Asian, Chinese, Black, Filipino, Latin American, Arab, Southeast Asian, West Asian, Korean and Japanese.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2019_ms_famstr_cen
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Census Families by Family Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for census families by family structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for census families by family structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_hh_maintainer
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Households by Maintainer Age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for households by maintainer age. According the Statistics Canada, Household Maintainer refers to whether or not a person residing in the household is responsible for paying the rent, or the mortgage, or the taxes, or the electricity or other services or utilities. Where a number of people may contribute to the payments, more than one person in the household may be identified as a household maintainer. If no person in the household is identified as making such payments, the reference person is identified by default. Household refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_hh_size
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Households by Size of Household variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for households by size of household. According to Statistics Canada, 'Household size' refers to the number of persons in a private household. 'Private household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The household universe is divided into two sub-universes on the basis of whether the household is occupying a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The latter is a private household. For census purposes, households are classified into three groups: private households, collective households and households outside Canada. Unless otherwise specified, all data in census products are for private households only.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for households by size of household. According to Statistics Canada, 'Household size' refers to the number of persons in a private household. 'Private household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The household universe is divided into two sub-universes on the basis of whether the household is occupying a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The latter is a private household. For census purposes, households are classified into three groups: private households, collective households and households outside Canada. Unless otherwise specified, all data in census products are for private households only.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_hh_type
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Households by Household Type variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for households by holdhold type. According Statistics Canada, 'Household type' refers to the differentiation of households on the basis of whether they are census family households or non-census-family households. Census family households are those that contain at least one census family. Non-census-family households are either one person living alone or a group of two or more persons who live together but do not constitute a census family. Census family households may be differentiated based on the presence of additional persons (that is, persons not in a census family).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_hs_condo_stat
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Occupied Private Dwellings by Condo Status, Tenure & Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for occupied private dwellings by condo status, tenure and structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Condominium status' refers to whether the private dwelling is part of a condominium development. A condominium is a residential complex in which dwellings are owned individually while land and common elements are held in joint ownership with others. 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Tenure' refers to whether the household owns or rents their private dwelling. The private dwelling may be situated on rented or leased land or be part of a condominium. A household is considered to own their dwelling if some member of the household owns the dwelling even if it is not fully paid for, for example if there is a mortgage or some other claim on it. A household is considered to rent their dwelling if no member of the household owns the dwelling. A household is considered to rent that dwelling even if the dwelling is provided without cash rent or at a reduced rent, or if the dwelling is part of a cooperative.

'Period of construction' refers to the period in time during which the building or dwelling was originally constructed. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_inc_constant
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Housholds by Income (Constant Year) variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for households by income (constant year - 2015). According Statistics Canada, 'constant dollar' refers to dollars of several years expressed in terms of their value ("purchasing power") in a single year, called the base year. This type of adjustment is done to eliminate the impact of widespread price changes. 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_job_industry
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population 15 Years of Over by Industry variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for 5 household population 15 years or over by industry. According to Statistics Canada, 'Industry' refers to a generally homogeneous group of economic producing units, primarily engaged in a specific set of activities. An activity is a particular method of combining goods and services inputs, labour and capital to produce one or more goods and/or services (products). In most cases, the activities that define an industry are homogeneous with respect to the production processes used (based on the North American Industry Classification System [NAICS] 2012).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_job_labour
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population 15 Years or Over by Labour Force Activity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2020. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2020. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_job_occupation
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 household population 15 years or over by occupation variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population15 years or over by occupation. According Statistics Canada, 'Occupation' refers to the kind of work performed in a job, a job being all the tasks carried out by a particular worker to complete his or her duties. An occupation is a set of jobs that are sufficiently similar in work performed. Kind of work is described in terms of tasks, duties and responsibilities, often including factors such as materials processed or used, the industrial processes used, the equipment used, and the products or services provided. Occupations are generally homogeneous with respect to skill type and skill level. Occupation applies to the contribution of labour to that part of economic activity that is within the production boundary defined for the System of National Accounts. (based on the National Occupational Classification [NOC] 2016).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_li_aboriginal
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Aboriginal Identity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by aboriginal identity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Aboriginal identity' refers to whether the person identified with the Aboriginal peoples of Canada. This includes those who are First Nations (North American Indian), Métis or Inuk (Inuit) and/or those who are Registered or Treaty Indians (that is, registered under the Indian Act of Canada), and/or those who have membership in a First Nation or Indian band. Aboriginal peoples of Canada are defined in the Constitution Act, 1982, Section 35 (2) as including the Indian, Inuit and Métis peoples of Canada.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by aboriginal identity. Aboriginal peoples of Canada are defined in the Constitution Act, 1982, Section 35 (2) as including the Indian, Inuit and Métis peoples of Canada.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_li_lang_official
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Knowledge of Official Language variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by knowledge of official languages. According to Statistics Canada, 'Knowledge of official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in English only, French only, in both or in neither language. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. 'Knowledge of non-official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in a language other than English or French. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. The number of languages that can be reported may vary between surveys, depending on the objectives of the survey.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_li_mthr_tongue
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Mother Tongue variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by mother tongue. According to Statistics Canada, 'Mother tongue' refers to the first language learned at home in childhood and still understood by the person at the time the data was collected. If the person no longer understands the first language learned, the mother tongue is the second language learned. For a person who learned two languages at the same time in early childhood, the mother tongue is the language this person spoke most often at home before starting school. The person has two mother tongues only if the two languages were used equally often and are still understood by the person. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, the mother tongue is the language spoken most often to this child at home. The child has two mother tongues only if both languages are spoken equally often so that the child learns both languages at the same time.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_li_vis_minority
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Visible Minority Status variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by visible minority status. According to Statistics Canada, 'Visible minority' refers to whether a person belongs to a visible minority group as defined by the Employment Equity Act and, if so, the visible minority group to which the person belongs. The Employment Equity Act defines visible minorities as "persons, other than Aboriginal peoples, who are non-Caucasian in race or non-white in colour". The visible minority population consists mainly of the following groups: South Asian, Chinese, Black, Filipino, Latin American, Arab, Southeast Asian, West Asian, Korean and Japanese.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_ms_famstr_cen
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Census Families by Family Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for census families by family structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children.
