Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_ms_famstr_hh
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Census Family Households by Family Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for census family households by family structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children. 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2020_prizm_hh
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 PRIZM5 Household Count variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for PRIZM household counts. Environics PRIZM classifies Canada's neighbourhoods into 68 unique lifestyle types by integrating geographic, demographic and psychographic data. According to Statistics Canada, 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2019 Households by Maintainer Age variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2019 census data for households by maintainer age. According the Statistics Canada, Household Maintainer refers to whether or not a person residing in the household is responsible for paying the rent, or the mortgage, or the taxes, or the electricity or other services or utilities. Where a number of people may contribute to the payments, more than one person in the household may be identified as a household maintainer. If no person in the household is identified as making such payments, the reference person is identified by default. Household refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_hh_size
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Households by Size of Household variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for households by size of household. According to Statistics Canada, 'Household size' refers to the number of persons in a private household. 'Private household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The household universe is divided into two sub-universes on the basis of whether the household is occupying a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The latter is a private household. For census purposes, households are classified into three groups: private households, collective households and households outside Canada. Unless otherwise specified, all data in census products are for private households only.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_hh_type
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Households by Household Type variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for households by holdhold type. According Statistics Canada, 'Household type' refers to the differentiation of households on the basis of whether they are census family households or non-census-family households. Census family households are those that contain at least one census family. Non-census-family households are either one person living alone or a group of two or more persons who live together but do not constitute a census family. Census family households may be differentiated based on the presence of additional persons (that is, persons not in a census family).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_hs_condo_stat
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Occupied Private Dwellings by Condo Status, Tenure & Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for occupied private dwellings by condo status, tenure and structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Condominium status' refers to whether the private dwelling is part of a condominium development. A condominium is a residential complex in which dwellings are owned individually while land and common elements are held in joint ownership with others. 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Tenure' refers to whether the household owns or rents their private dwelling. The private dwelling may be situated on rented or leased land or be part of a condominium. A household is considered to own their dwelling if some member of the household owns the dwelling even if it is not fully paid for, for example if there is a mortgage or some other claim on it. A household is considered to rent their dwelling if no member of the household owns the dwelling. A household is considered to rent that dwelling even if the dwelling is provided without cash rent or at a reduced rent, or if the dwelling is part of a cooperative.

'Tenure' refers to whether the household owns or rents their private dwelling. The private dwelling may be situated on rented or leased land or be part of a condominium. A household is considered to own their dwelling if some member of the household owns the dwelling even if it is not fully paid for, for example if there is a mortgage or some other claim on it. A household is considered to rent their dwelling if no member of the household owns the dwelling. A household is considered to rent that dwelling even if the dwelling is provided without cash rent or at a reduced rent, or if the dwelling is part of a cooperative.

Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Occupied Private Dwellings by Period of Construction variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for occupied private dwellings by period of construction. According to Statistics Canada, 'Private dwelling' refers to a separate set of living quarters with a private entrance either from outside the building or from a common hall, lobby, vestibule or stairway inside the building. The entrance to the dwelling must be one that can be used without passing through the living quarters of some other person or group of persons. 'Period of construction' refers to the period in time during which the building or dwelling was originally constructed. This refers to the period in which the building was completed, not the time of any later remodelling, additions or conversions.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_inc_constant
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Housholds by Income (Constant Year) variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for households by income (constant year - 2015). According Statistics Canada, 'constant dollar' refers to dollars of several years expressed in terms of their value ("purchasing power") in a single year, called the base year. This type of adjustment is done to eliminate the impact of widespread price changes. 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_job_industry
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population 15 Years of Over by Industry variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for 5 household population 15 years or over by industry. According to Statistics Canada, 'Industry' refers to a generally homogeneous group of economic producing units, primarily engaged in a specific set of activities. An activity is a particular method of combining goods and services inputs, labour and capital to produce one or more goods and/or services (products). In most cases, the activities that define an industry are homogeneous with respect to the production processes used (based on the North American Industry Classification System [NAICS] 2012).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_job_labour
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population 15 Years or Over by Labour Force Activity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2020. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population 15 years or over by labour force activity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Labour Force' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were either employed or unemployed as this data has been enhanced the reference date would be May 7, 2020. Labour force = Employed + Unemployed. 'Employed person' refers to those who, during the reference period, had a labour force status of 'employed'. That is, those who, during the reference period: (a) Did any work at all at a job or business, that is, paid work in the context of an employer-employee relationship, or self-employment. This also includes persons who did unpaid family work, which is defined as unpaid work contributing directly to the operation of a farm, business or professional practice owned and operated by a related member of the same household; or (b) Had a job but were not at work due to factors such as their own illness or disability, personal or family responsibilities, vacation or a labour dispute. This category excludes persons not at work because they were on layoff or between casual jobs, and those who did not then have a job (even if they had a job to start at a future date). 'Unemployed' refers to persons who, during the week of Sunday, May 1 to Saturday, May 7, 2016, were without paid work or without self-employment work and were available for work and either: (a) had actively looked for paid work in the past four weeks; or (b) were on temporary lay-off and expected to return to their job; or (c) had definite arrangements to start a new job in four weeks or less.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_job_occupation
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 household population 15 years or over by occupation variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population15 years or over by occupation. According Statistics Canada, 'Occupation' refers to the kind of work performed in a job, a job being all the tasks carried out by a particular worker to complete his or her duties. An occupation is a set of jobs that are sufficiently similar in work performed. Kind of work is described in terms of tasks, duties and responsibilities, often including factors such as materials processed or used, the industrial processes used, the equipment used, and the products or services provided. Occupations are generally homogeneous with respect to skill type and skill level. Occupation applies to the contribution of labour to that part of economic activity that is within the production boundary defined for the System of National Accounts. (based on the National Occupational Classification [NOC] 2016).

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_li_aboriginal
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Aboriginal Identity variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by aboriginal identity. According to Statistics Canada, 'Aboriginal identity' refers to whether the person identified with the Aboriginal peoples of Canada. This includes those who are First Nations (North American Indian), Métis or Inuk (Inuit) and/or those who are Registered or Treaty Indians (that is, registered under the Indian Act of Canada), and/or those who have membership in a First Nation or Indian band. Aboriginal peoples of Canada are defined in the Constitution Act, 1982, Section 35 (2) as including the Indian, Inuit and Métis peoples of Canada.

Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by recent immigrants and place of birth. According to Statistics Canada, 'Immigrant' refers to a person who is, or who has ever been, a landed immigrant or permanent resident. Such a person has been granted the right to live in Canada permanently by immigration authorities. Immigrants who have obtained Canadian citizenship by naturalization are included in this group.

According to Statistics Canada, 'Language spoken most often at home' refers to the language the person speaks most often at home at the time of data collection. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_li_lang_official
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Knowledge of Official Language variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by knowledge of official languages. According to Statistics Canada, 'Knowledge of official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in English only, French only, in both or in neither language. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. 'Knowledge of non-official languages' refers to whether the person can conduct a conversation in a language other than English or French. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, this includes languages that the child is learning to speak at home. The number of languages that can be reported may vary between surveys, depending on the objectives of the survey.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_li_mthr_tongue
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Mother Tongue variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by mother tongue. According to Statistics Canada, 'Mother tongue' refers to the first language learned at home in childhood and still understood by the person at the time the data was collected. If the person no longer understands the first language learned, the mother tongue is the second language learned. For a person who learned two languages at the same time in early childhood, the mother tongue is the language this person spoke most often at home before starting school. The person has two mother tongues only if the two languages were used equally often and are still understood by the person. For a child who has not yet learned to speak, the mother tongue is the language spoken most often to this child at home. The child has two mother tongues only if both languages are spoken equally often so that the child learns both languages at the same time.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_li_vis_minority
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Household Population by Visible Minority Status variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for household population by visible minority status. According to Statistics Canada, 'Visible minority' refers to whether a person belongs to a visible minority group as defined by the Employment Equity Act and, if so, the visible minority group to which the person belongs. The Employment Equity Act defines visible minorities as "persons, other than Aboriginal peoples, who are non-Caucasian in race or non-white in colour". The visible minority population consists mainly of the following groups: South Asian, Chinese, Black, Filipino, Latin American, Arab, Southeast Asian, West Asian, Korean and Japanese.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_ms_famstr_cen
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Census Families by Family Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for census families by family structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_DA_2022_ms_famstr_hh
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created through the ESRI Data Enrichment Tool. The Open Data Census 2016 Dissemination Areas dataset was enriched using the 2020 Census Family Households by Family Structure variable.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistic Canada 2016 Census Dissemination Areas with enhanced 2020 census data for census family households by family structure. According to Statistics Canada, 'Marital status' refers to whether or not a person is living in a common-law union as well as the legal marital status of those who are not living in a common-law union. All persons aged less than 15 are considered as never married and not living common law. 'Census family' is defined as a married couple and the children, if any, of either and/or both spouses; a couple living common law and the children, if any, of either and/or both partners; or a lone parent of any marital status with at least one child living in the same dwelling and that child or those children. All members of a particular census family live in the same dwelling. A couple may be of opposite or same sex. Children may be children by birth, marriage, common-law union or adoption regardless of their age or marital status as long as they live in the dwelling and do not have their own married spouse, common-law partner or child living in the dwelling. Grandchildren living with their grandparent(s) but with no parents present also constitute a census family. 'Census family structure' refers to the combination of relatives that comprise a census family. Classification on this variable considers the presence or absence of: married spouses or common-law partners and children. 'Household' refers to a person or group of persons who occupy the same dwelling and do not have a usual place of residence elsewhere in Canada or abroad. The dwelling may be either a collective dwelling or a private dwelling. The household may consist of a family group such as a census family, of two or more families sharing a dwelling, of a group of unrelated persons or of a person living alone. Household members who are temporarily absent on reference day are considered part of their usual household.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_dissemination_area_2016
Datasets.Description: This dataset is a compilation of Statistics Canada Dissemination Areas with associated population data from the 2016 Census. According to Statistics Canada, a dissemination area (DA) is a small, relatively stable geographic unit composed of one or more adjacent dissemination blocks with an average population of 400 to 700 persons based on data from the previous Census of Population Program. It is the smallest standard geographic area for which all census data are disseminated.
Datasets.Summary: This dataset was created for statistical purposes and to perform population calculations.  It can be used as a base for all Statistics Canada tabular data that is at the Dissemination level.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_dissemination_block_2016
Datasets.Description: This dataset is a complitation of Statistics Canada Dissemination Block with associated population data from the 2016 Census. According to Statistics Canada, a Dissemination Block (DB) is an area bounded on all sides by roads and/or boundaries of standard geographic areas and is the smallest geographic area for which population and dwelling count data are disseminated. The orignal file contain the boundaries of all dissemination blocks which combine to cover all of Canadabut this feature class represents only the dissemination blocks for Halifax Regional Municipality.
Datasets.Summary: This dataset was created for statistical purposes and to perform population calculations.
Datasets.Purpose: This dataset was created for statistical purposes and to perform population calculations.

Datasets.UseConstraints: There are several dissemination blocks that do not have population data because it was not available through Statistics Canada. The reason could be that the dissemination block was so small there was no population or the dissemination block could be located within a First Nations Reserve and information was not permitted or available to the 2016 Census. The dissemination block that do not have population information are: 12090587002, 12090587003, 12090588001, 12090588002, 12090590001, 12090716001, 12091001001, 12091002001, 12091002002, 12091002003, 12091003001

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_socio_economic_indicators
Datasets.Description:
The Community Environs (COMe) geographies represent clusters of population and neighborhoods sharing identity and social processes, including access to healthcare services. This feature class includes the Material Security (MS) and Social Connectivity (SC) Indicators, which are composite measures of socio-economic conditions experienced by communities. These indicators are derived from census data, showing 5 levels of security and connectivity based on PCA without age standardization.

Variables contributing to the Material Security indicator (MS):

- % Low Education Level

- % Unemployment Rate

- Average Individual Income, $

- % Incidence Low Income After Tax (20-64 years)

- % Incidence Low Income After Tax (65+ years)

- % Government Transfer Payments

- % Spend 30% Income on Shelter

- % Living in Household in need of Major Repairs

- Average Value of Dwelling

Variables contributing to the Social Connectivity indicator (SC):

- % Separated, Divorced, Widowed

- % Single Parent Families

- % Person Living Alone

- % Recent Movers

- % Recent Immigrant

- % Speaking no Official Language at Home

- % Visible Minority

These variables were used to create quintiles for both MS and SC, ranging from 1 (low security/connectivity) to 5 (high security/connectivity). The methodology follows the Deprivation Index of Canada, without age standardization, and with MS and SC derived from two independent PCA processes.

Other variables of interest not included in the area-based SES summary indicators:

- Population Count

- Female Population

- Male Population

- Average Age

- Median Individual Income, $

- % Renter

- % Subhousing

- % Refugee

- % Population 65+, living alone

- % Population age 0-9

- % Population age 20-29

- % Population age 50-74

- % Population aged 65 years and older

These variables, while not part of the SES (Socio-Economic Status) summary indicators, provide additional insights into the demographics and living conditions within the COMe geographies.
Datasets.Summary: This feature class contains indicators of Material Security (MS) and Social Connectivity (SC) for Community Environs (COMe), reflecting socio-economic conditions based on census data. MS and SC indicators are derived from census variables using principal component analysis (PCA) and grouped into quintiles to reflect community well-being.
Datasets.Purpose: This feature class contains indicators of Material Security (MS) and Social Connectivity (SC) for Community Environs (COMe), reflecting socio-economic conditions based on census data. MS and SC indicators are derived from census variables using principal component analysis (PCA) and grouped into quintiles to reflect community well-being.
Datasets.Tags: Community Environs, Material Security, Social Connectivity, Socio-Economic Indicators, Census Data, Deprivation Index, Nova Scotia Health, HRM, PCA, Custom Geography
Datasets.Credits:
Some data is derived from Statistics Canada. Adapted by Dr. Nathalie Saint-Jacques (Nova Scotia Health), based on data from the Census Profile. This feature class incorporates data obtained under the Statistics Canada Open License and has been modified to fit custom geographic boundaries. Statistics Canada is not responsible for the derivation, interpretation, or analysis of the data.

Where you use the data in a report or publication, reference their sources as per the following:

SES indices: 
Socio-Economic Status (SES) Reports - Cancer Care Program - Staff and Physicians - LibGuides at Nova Scotia Health
(https://library.nshealth.ca/Staff-Cancer-Care/SES)

Community Environs geography: 
Small-area spatio-temporal analysis of cancer risk to support effective and equitable cancer prevention | PLOS One
(https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0325523)
Datasets.UseConstraints: This data cannot be shared outside of HRM. Data must not be averaged across other geographies. COMe geographies are custom-built and data applies solely to this unit. Results should be used with caution outside of these bounds.
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: The Community Environs (COMe) geographies represent… | Tags: Community Environs, Material Security, Social Connectivity, Socio-Economic Indicators, Census Data, Deprivation Index, Nova Scotia Health, HRM, PCA, Custom Geography

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CON_contour_10k
Datasets.Description: 3D contours from 10k mapping for Halifax and Hants counties. February 2013 - Additional contours were derived from a 2007 airborne LiDAR 1 metre resolution DEM (digital elevation model) that HRM had flown. The DEM derived contours in the LiDAR flight area were amalgamated with existing photogrametrically created 5m contours. There will be some mismatches in postion and snapping where the boundary between the DEM and photogrammetric contours abut.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.FLD_fp_StudyAreas
Datasets.Description:
This dataset consolidates modeled floodplain extents from multiple hydrologic and climate resilience studies conducted across select watersheds in the Halifax Regional Municipality. Included are flood risk extents for:

- Sackville River & Little Sackville River (CBCL 2017, DesignPoint 2024)

- Shubenacadie Lakes region (CBCL 2020)

Polygons represent modeled flood plains for various return periods (e.g., 1 in 20 year, 1 in 100 year), with relevant hydrologic and climate parameters captured in the attribute fields. All data support planning and development processes and are not intended to represent official regulatory boundaries.

Each polygon includes a case study identifier (e.g., “SR”, “SL”) and model-specific information including AEP, return period, projection horizon, storm event characteristics, and source information among other specifications.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representations of modeled floodplain extents for select Halifax watersheds including the Sackville River system and the Shubenacadie Lakes. Compiled from multiple case studies to support land use planning and climate adaptation.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representations of modeled floodplain extents for select Halifax watersheds including the Sackville River system and the Shubenacadie Lakes. Compiled from multiple case studies to support land use planning and climate adaptation.
Datasets.Tags: Halifax, Sackville River, Little Sackville River, Shubenacadie Lakes, Lake Charles, Portobello, Flooding, Floodplain, Planning, Development, Halifax Open Data, Climate Change, LiDAR, Watershed, AEP, 2100, 2020, 2017, 2024
Datasets.Credits:
- Sackville River Floodplain Study – Phase II, CBCL Limited, 2017
- Sackville River Floodplain Update, DesignPoint Engineering & Surveying, 2024
- Shubenacadie Lakes Floodplain Study, CBCL Limited, 2020
Datasets.UseConstraints: To be used for Land Use Planning purposes only. This dataset reflects modeled outputs from engineering studies and does not represent regulatory boundaries or approved policies. Consult the original study documents for further detail.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_ANS_communities
Datasets.Description: This polygon feature class comprises the polygon boundaries of African Nova Scotian Communities within the municipality. The dataset delineates the spatial extent of these communities, providing planners and decision-makers with geospatial information essential for strategic planning and development initiatives. By leveraging this dataset, stakeholders can identify and map the designated African Nova Scotian Communities, facilitating targeted interventions to foster inclusive growth, economic prosperity, and community well-being.
Datasets.Summary: On April 4, 2023, the Regional Council endorsed the 2023-26 updated Road to Economic Prosperity for African Nova Scotian Communities: Summary Report and Action Plan (REPAC), marking a significant milestone in the municipality's commitment to fostering healthy, livable communities and promoting economic development. This endorsement underscores a coordinated effort outlined in the Halifax Economic Growth Plan 2016-2021 to achieve tangible and measurable results in African Nova Scotian Communities. The purpose of this dataset is to support this commitment by providing spatial data to planners and decision-makers.
Datasets.Purpose: On April 4, 2023, the Regional Council endorsed the 2023-26 updated Road to Economic Prosperity for African Nova Scotian Communities: Summary Report and Action Plan (REPAC), marking a significant milestone in the municipality's commitment to fostering healthy, livable communities and promoting economic development. This endorsement underscores a coordinated effort outlined in the Halifax Economic Growth Plan 2016-2021 to achieve tangible and measurable results in African Nova Scotian Communities. The purpose of this dataset is to support this commitment by providing spatial data to planners and decision-makers.
Datasets.Tags: Community Boundaries, African Nova Scotian Communities, Planning, ANSAIO

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_area_rate_fire_protection
Datasets.Description: Boundary delineating the parcels within one kilometer of any fire hydrant used for fire protection. Some hydrants such as the the one in Musquodoboit are for flushing only, and are therefore excluded from this faeture class. This layer was generated using Network Analyst, creating a network service line 1200 feet less 50 metres from every hydrant point. The service line was then buffered by 50 metres. This was done to intersect all parcels on either side of a right-of-way, including wide boulevards and cul-de-sacs. The 50 metre buffer does present some problems of intersecting the backs of parcels through the shorter lots. Upon having all the intersected parcels, they were merged together, and has topology rules applied to avoid gaps and overlaps. Water courses and/or crown land that was "land-locked" by the merged parcels were incorporated into the boundary. Water courses and/or crown lands that were on the fringe of the merged parcels were removed to reduce the size of the boundary layer. Where appropriate, parcels not intersected by the service line buffer, but that are clearly serviced within one kilometre are included. These may include adjoining water lots that share the same AAN.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_area_rate_transit
Datasets.Description: Boundary delineating the parcels within one kilometer of any Metro Transit bus stop or community transit route. This layer was generated using Network Analyst, creating a network service line 950 metres from every stop point. The service line was then buffered by 50 metres. This was done to intersect all parcels on either side of a right-of-way, including wide boulevards and cul-de-sacs. The 50 metre buffer does present some problems of intersecting the backs of parcels through the shorter lots. Upon having all the intersected parcels, they were merged together, and has topology rules applied to avoid gaps and overlaps. Water courses and/or crown land that was "land-locked" by the merged parcels were incorporated into the boundary. Water courses and/or crown lands that were on the fringe of the merged parcels were removed to reduce the size of the boundary layer. Where appropriate, parcels not intersected by the service line buffer, but that are clearly serviced within one kilometre are included. These may include adjoining water lots that share the same AAN.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_business_park
Datasets.Description: The Business Parks Functional Plan is one of the mechanisms for implementing HRM’s Regional Municipal Planning Strategy, which was approved in 2006. The Business Parks Functional Plan (BPFP) serves as a strategic plan for the future expansion of business parks and ensuring adequate supply of industrial lands within HRM. There are thirteen (13) business parks in HRM owned by the municipality and the province, plus an additional three owned by the private sector. The HRM owns and operates six (6) business parks in HRM (Burnside, City of Lakes, Bayers Lake, Aerotech, Ragged Lake, and Lakeside), while the Province manages seven (7) parks (Sackville, Woodside, Atlantic Acres, Bedford, Eastern Shore, Musquodoboit Harbour and Sheet Harbour) through Nova Scotia Business Inc. (NSBI). The three privately owned parks in HRM Dartmouth Crossing, Bedford Commons, and West Bedford Business Campus, include a total of 950 acres of land, and focus on providing for retail and office uses.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_elevated_arch_potential
Datasets.Description: Archaeological resources are the remains of any building, structure, activity, place or cultural feature or object that, because of the passage of time, is on or below the surface of land or water and is of significance to the understanding of the history of a people or place. These sites are protected under provincial legislation, the Special Places Protection Act, which regulates the destruction, alteration or removal of archaeological resources from these sites.
Datasets.Summary: In conjunction with the Heritage Division of the Nova Scotia Department of Tourism, Culture and Heritage, HRM has prepared the Areas of Elevated Archaeological Potential Map (Map 11) to identify areas with high potential to contain archaeological resources from the period of time preceding European settlement. The development of these sites could present a significant risk to archaeological resources. If these sites are recognized and appropriately addressed prior to development taking place, adverse consequences can be mitigated and archaeological resources preserved.
Datasets.Purpose: In conjunction with the Heritage Division of the Nova Scotia Department of Tourism, Culture and Heritage, HRM has prepared the Areas of Elevated Archaeological Potential Map (Map 11) to identify areas with high potential to contain archaeological resources from the period of time preceding European settlement. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_floodplain_overlay
Datasets.Description: The Floodway Overlay Zones and the Areas Requiring Modified Floodproofing are overlaying existing zones to help implement floodplain protection polices outlined within each plan. The 1 in 20 year Floodway Overlay (FWO) Zone, the 1 in 100 year Flood Fringe Overlay (FFO) Zone, and the Modified Floodproofing (MFP) measures help delineate areas of controlled development and constraints in land use planning within the Sackville and Little Sackville River areas.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of the Floodplain Overlay Zones and Areas Requiring Modified Floodproofing within the Sackville and Little Sackville River area, which delineates areas of controlled development and constraints based on 2024 floodplain study.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of the Floodplain Overlay Zones and Areas Requiring Modified Floodproofing within the Sackville and Little Sackville River area, which delineates areas of controlled development and constraints based on 2024 floodplain study.
Datasets.Tags: Floodplain Overlay Zones, Sackville River, Little Sackville River, Floodway Fringe, Modified Floodproofing

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_indigenous_lands
Datasets.Description:
This dataset captures lands where title is either:

- vested through legislation or land claim agreements, or

- identified through internal processes as Indigenous-owned or under Indigenous stewardship, though not necessarily defined under federal or provincial Acts.

It includes Legislated Aboriginal Lands (federally used terminology), such as Indian Reserves (as per the Indian Act), and further, if applicable: Land claim settlement lands, other specific legislated areas.

It further includes Indigenous-Owned Lands:

- Lands identified by internal consultation or other sources as being owned, managed, or held in trust for Indigenous groups, but not captured by formal legislative boundaries.

- These may include lands purchased, gifted, or recognized by Indigenous entities, and are typically confirmed through parcel identification and land registry references.

The dataset supports reconciliation, land use planning, planning projects, and decision-making efforts. This is maintained by the Office of Diversity and Inclusion.

The use of some of the data does not imply endorsement by the Government of Canada. Any interpretations or decisions made based on this data are the sole responsibility of the user.
Datasets.Summary:
The Indigenous Lands feature class consists of polygon features depicting lands associated with Indigenous groups in Halifax Regional Municipality, including both legislated administrative boundaries (e.g. reservation lands) and Indigenous-owned lands.

Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence – Canada.
Source: Aboriginal Lands of Canada Legislative Boundaries, retrieved from https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/522b07b9-78e2-4819-b736-ad9208eb1067
Datasets.Purpose:
The Indigenous Lands feature class consists of polygon features depicting lands associated with Indigenous groups in Halifax Regional Municipality, including both legislated administrative boundaries (e.g. reservation lands) and Indigenous-owned lands.

Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence – Canada.

Datasets.Tags: Indigenous Lands, First Nations, Indian Reserves, Settlement Lands, Indigenous-Owned Land, Land Use Planning, DEI, Reconciliation, Land Stewardship, Territorial Rights, Administrative Boundaries, Indigenous Reserve Lands
Datasets.Credits:
"This dataset is compiled and maintained by the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DEI) Office in collaboration with the P&D and GIS.

Source data is derived from:
- Provincial and federal open data portals, including legislated reserve boundaries and land claim settlement areas.
- Internal land registry analysis and engagements to identify Indigenous-owned parcels not reflected in public legislative datasets.
- Contributions from subject matter experts and engagement with key partners.

The dataset leverages information developed and maintained by:
- Natural Resources Canada (NRCan)
- Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs Canada (CIRNAC)
- Provincial geospatial authorities

Contains information licensed under the Open Government License – Canada.
Source: Aboriginal Lands of Canada Legislative Boundaries, retrieved from https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/522b07b9-78e2-4819-b736-ad9208eb1067"
Datasets.UseConstraints:
"This dataset is provided for planning, policy, and reference purposes only and does not constitute legal land status.

Users are responsible for validating boundaries and classifications with authoritative sources before use in legal or transactional contexts.

Portions of this dataset contain information licensed under the Open Government License – Canada. You may:

- Copy, modify, publish, translate, adapt, distribute, or otherwise use the Information for any lawful purpose, including commercial use,

- Provided that attribution is maintained as described under the license terms.

This license does not permit:

- Use of personal information,

- Third-party rights the Information Provider cannot license,

- Use of official symbols, logos, or endorsements,

- Any assertion of official status or endorsement by the Government of Canada.

The data is provided ""as is"" without warranty or liability."

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_outdoor_rec_poly
Datasets.Description:
Polygons representing outdoor recreation areas such active use areas (playgrounds, , sportsfields, sportscourts, ball diamonds and water-related activity areas.

LND_outdoor_rec_poly has a relationship class to the LND_outdoor_rec_use table. The relationship links assets to the use(s) of those assets, e.g., a sportscourt is used as a basketball court.

LND_outdoor_rec_poly has a relationship class to the LND_outdoor_rec_equip_point feature class. The relationship links assets such as sportscourts (polygons) to basketball hoops (points).

LND_outdoor_rec_poly has a relationship to LND_park_recreation_feature, which identifies outdoor recreation polygon assets or groups of assets for mapping purposes.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_PPLC_Building_Permits
Datasets.Description:
The dataset was created to show a spatial representation of the building permits. This dataset contains all permits under the following permit types: Residential Building, Mixed Use & Commercial Building Permits.

Statuses of permits include from submission through to issuance and completion. Permits are spatially represented based on civic address. If no civic address is assigned to permit, then the point location is created in the center of the parcel.

Datasets.Description:
The dataset was created to show a spatial representation of the engineer permits. This dataset contains all permits under the following permit types: Blasting Permits, Development - Right of Way Permits, Grade Alteration Permits and Lot Grading Permits.

Statuses of permits include from submission through to issuance and completion. Permits are spatially represented based on civic address. If no civic address is assigned to permit, then the point location is created in the center of the parcel.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_special_planning_areas
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created to support the development of Provincial Special Planning Areas (SPAs) designated under the Housing in the Halifax Regional Municipality Act. The dataset delineates these areas from other lands not covered by the Act. These areas were established to accelerate housing supply by granting the Minister of Growth and Development authority over planning decisions within them.
Datasets.Summary: The Province of Nova Scotia has created an Executive Panel on Housing to address housing challenges in the capital region. As part of this initiative, the Minister of Growth and Development has designated Provincial Special Planning Areas (SPAs) within the Halifax Regional Municipality. This dataset represents the boundaries of those areas.
Datasets.Purpose: The Province of Nova Scotia has created an Executive Panel on Housing to address housing challenges in the capital region. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_zoning
Datasets.Description:
Land use zone applied to a particular area of land within a land use by-law (LUB) area. The zone value of each polygon corresponds with a zone in the associated land use by-law, which lists permitted or prohibited uses for each zone.

Land use zones differ between LUB areas, so each zone must be interpreted within the context of the LUB area in which it is applied.
Datasets.Summary: To determine permitted or prohibited land uses according to the provisions of the land use by-laws within HRM.
Datasets.Purpose: To determine permitted or prohibited land uses according to the provisions of the land use by-laws within HRM.
Datasets.Tags: Zoning, Planning, Plan, Halifax, HRM, Nova Scotia, Land Use By-law, Zone, Development, Bylaw
Datasets.UseConstraints: The complete package of zoning regulations varies for each land use by-law area. Reference to the complete package, together with the full text of the land use by-law, must be made in order to determine the permitted land uses and requirements for any land in HRM. Complete information for each land use by-law is available from HRM Development Approvals.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.MAP_abandoned_mine
Datasets.Description: This digital product is developed from a database of published abandoned mine openings for the province of Nova Scotia. The database is maintained by the Nova Scotia Department of Energy and Mines (NSDEM), Geoscience and Mines Branch (GMB). The digital product was created by the NSDEM GMB staff. The database provides approximate coordinate locations for many of the abandoned mine openings, and also provides a source reference on each mine opening.
Datasets.Summary: To identify the location of abandoned mine openings with the hope of presenting potential mineral rights holders with a province wide overview of the locations of past mineral production and an exploration guide to finding new deposits.
Datasets.Purpose: To identify the location of abandoned mine openings with the hope of presenting potential mineral rights holders with a province wide overview of the locations of past mineral production and an exploration guide to finding new deposits.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_forest
Datasets.Description: GIS thematic layer containing polygons for all lands in Nova Scotia. Includes water, forest, and non-forest areas, with a primary focus on identifying the attributes of forested land.The source data was obtained by interpretation of 1:10,000 aerial photography and updated by applying change detection algorithms to satellite imagery, and treatment information obtained from various ground sources (GPS, compass and stringbox). New imagery is obtained for approximately 10% of the province each year. In this imagery, only areas enduring distrubance or having a height greater than or equal to 13 metres are reinterpreted. Areas of harvests and partial cuts updated from satellite imagery are locationally correct, but may not have an exact representation of the boundaries due to pixel size. These areas have been entered on the interim between photo interpretation to allow for on-going forestry analysis. The boundaries will be refined as photo re-interpretation occurs.

Datasets.Purpose: To provide information relating to Nova Scotia's forest resources.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_riparian_buffer
Datasets.Description: Removal of vegetation adjacent to waterbodies has a major impact on wildlife and aquatic habitat as well as on water quality. The adoption of policy recommendations arising from the HRM Water Resources Management Study (WRMS) could include 20 m. protective buffers for all waterbodies. Buffers could be extended beyond the 20 m. minimum distance by HRM based on local slope and soil conditions however for the purposes of this study waterbodies have been buffered to 20 metres.
Datasets.Summary: Restrict development within a distance 20 metres from any watercourse.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_significant_habitat
Datasets.Description:
In the course of their regular duties and through contacts with other agencies, staff of the

Department of Natural Resources become aware of sites with unusual wildlife concentrations,

habitats used by species at risk, or habitats that are few in number within the province.

Recording information about these locations and making it available to appropriate agencies

and personnel, is the goal of the Significant Species and Habitats Project. The Project is

coordinated by the Manager Wildlife Resources, Terrestrial Habitat, Wildlife Division. Data is

assembled and recorded by the Regional Biologists and Wildlife Division staff. This document

explains the policy surrounding data collection, storage and access.

Landowners, resource companies, developers, utility companies, and governments at all levels

have an interest in the location of significant habitats so they can plan their activities

accordingly. Mapping known significant habitats is the first step in the management and

conservation of these sites. The mapping also plays a supportive role in the Department’s

Integrated Resource Management initiative, in impact assessment and natural resource

management planning by private agencies. The Significant Species and Habitat Project’s

overriding philosophy is that conservation of the site can only proceed if those involved have

knowledge of the information.

Project data bases include sensitive information. The widespread interest in significant habitats

data requires a policy that balances information access for management purposes with

information protection to prevent unauthorized or careless use of the sites. In addition, data is

partially collected from non DNR sources. To obtain this data, staff often need to assure the

owners that the information will be kept confidential and only available to persons with a

scientific or conservation interest in the site.

Users of the information should be aware that the data base is not a complete survey of all

significant habitats in the province. It should not be considered a planned inventory, nor

comprehensive.
Datasets.Tags: habitat species migratory bird deer concern
Datasets.Credits:
The Wildlife Division of the Department of Natural Resources, manages the project and is
responsible for project design, data base standards, and data release. They are also responsible
for the accuracy of the data they collect. The Division is responsible for making decisions
relative to the status, distribution, sensitivity to threats and potential impacts of development
on species and their habitats.

There is an extensive list of naturalists and institutions who have provided data to the project.
They are responsible for the accuracy of their data and have committed themselves to sharing
it with persons and institutions who have a scientific or conservation interest in the sites.
Institutional data sources outside DNR include: Acadia University, Canada Department of
Fisheries and Oceans, Canadian Lakes Loon Survey, Canadian Wildlife Service, Cape Breton
Highlands National Park, Fortress Louisbourg National Historic Site, Nova Scotia Museum of
Natural History, and University College of Cape Breton Herbarium.
Datasets.UseConstraints: Contact NSDNR Wildife with any inquiries.
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: In the course of their regu… | Tags: habitat species migratory bird deer concern

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_surficial_geology
Datasets.Description: This digital product is a compilation of surficial geological data of the Halifax Metropolitan area which was defined by Dan Utting using a LiDAR derived bare-earth hillshade model. The LiDAR data was collected by PHB Lasermap, and provided by Halifax Regional Municipality. The data was used to create Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources (NSDNR) Open File Maps OFM ME 2011-001 to 2011-012, compiled by D. J. Utting, 2011. The digital product was created by the NSDNR, Mineral Resources Branch (MRB) staff. The digital product contains layers for geological features such as: age dates, drumlins, eskers, geological contacts, surficial geologic units, ice movement, moraines, meltwater, neatline, station locations and large aggregate quarries.
Datasets.Summary: The purpose of this data set is to create a digital version of the surficial geology of the Halifax Metropolitan and surrounding areas, and to produce 11 new 1:25 000 maps. This digital product shows the surficial geology on parts of claim reference sheets: 11D/11B, 11D/11C, 11D/12A, 11D/12C, 11D/12D, 11D/13A, 11D/13B, 11D/13C, 11D/13D, 11D/14B, and 11D/14C,

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_surficial_geology_ns
Datasets.Description: This digital product (version 2 released as DP ME 1992-03) is a digital version of Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources (NSDNR) Published Map ME 1992-3, Surficial Geology Map of the Province of Nova Scotia, compiled by R.R. Stea, H. Conley and Y. Brown, 1992. The digital product was created by the NSDNR, Mineral Resources Branch (MRB) staff. The digital product was digitized from Map ME 1992-3 and the databases were developed from the information contained on this map. The digital product contains layers for surficial geology features such as: beaches, cirques, deltas, drumlins, eskers, surficial geological units, hummocks, kettles, morraines, meltwater, roche moutonnees, terrace scarps, glacial striations and other geological features. Version 2 of the product was released in 2006 in NAD83 and contained a number of thematic layers which were not included in version 1.

Datasets.Summary: Polygon area of the tree canopy coverage with associated DNRR Forest Inventory fire fuel types used to classify and represent the Canadian Fire Danger Rating System and Fire Behaviour fuel classification to aid experts in determining spread rates of wildfires.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon area of the tree canopy coverage with associated DNRR Forest Inventory fire fuel types used to classify and represent the Canadian Fire Danger Rating System and Fire Behaviour fuel classification to aid experts in determining spread rates of wildfires.

Datasets.Credits: Original source data (Tree Canopy Urban 2022) and (Tree Canopy Rural 2018) was clipped using the polygon boundaries of the (Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources Forest Inventory Layer , 2021) Urban Fire Fuel type. Dataset was altered to smooth the outline, remove holes under  5 m and remove polygons under 10 sqm.
Datasets.UseConstraints: The dataset is a work in progress, DNRR Forest Inventory fire fuel types domain has been added to the tree canopy fire fuel dataset and will be populated by HRFE as FireSmart assessments are  carried out to enhance the missing fire fuel data missing from the DNRR Forest Inventory.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_wetland_freshwater
Datasets.Description: The Nova Scotia Wetland Vegetation and Classification Inventory is based on the freshwater and salt marsh wetlands from the Nova Scotia Wetlands and Coastal Habitats Inventory (2000) dataset. This original inventory was developed to delineate and classify fresh and saltwater wetlands and coastal habitats to support policy and legislation, land use planning and impact assessment, environmental monitoring and reporting, and scientific research. All dominant wetlands and coastal habitat features greater than 0.5 hectares including bogs, fens, deep and shallow marshes, seasonally flooded flats, meadows, shrub and wooded swamps, lakeshore wetlands, salt marsh, saline ponds, dune, beach, cliff, and estuarine and marine flats were mapped using 1:10,000 airphoto interpretation. This dataset was integrated into the digital 1:10,000 forest cover from the Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources. Different years of photography were used for the counties. Cumberland County: 1985 and 1995; Colchester County: 1985 and 1994; Inverness, Victoria, Cape Breton, Richmond Counties: 1993; Kings, Annapolis, Queens, Lunenburg, Halifax, Hants Counties: 1992; Guysborough County: 1991; Pictou, Antigonish Counties: 1990 and 1997; Shelburne County: 1989; Yarmouth County: 1988 and 1989; Digby County: 1988. The above inventory took a number of years to complete. It was hoped that Landsat imagery could be used as a less costly and time consuming method of monitoring the changes within these delineated wetlands. At the same time this project was suggested, the new object oriented software program eCognition became available. ECognition uses segmentation which allows for grouping of pixels in a way that relates them to each other, as opposed to single pixels. As well membership functions, custom features, and nearest neighbour techniques can be used to classify the imagery. Essentially, the existing polygon boundaries were used and the classified vegetation types within were rolled up into the wetland types. Within the original wetland polygon it may say for example 20% treed bog and 80% shrub bog, but does not break down where these actually occur within the polygon. This method using eCognition does show where these different areas are.
Datasets.Summary: This product was developed to classify the wetlands in the Nova Scotia Wetlands and Coastal Habitats Inventory (2000) into vegetation types and then to roll up the vegetation into the 5 wetland classes recognized by the Canadian Wetlands Inventory (marsh, swamp, bog, fen, open water). This provided a way to update any changes that occurred in the wetland polygon after the initial inventory based on airphoto interpretation.
Datasets.Purpose: This product was developed to classify the wetlands in the Nova Scotia Wetlands and Coastal Habitats Inventory (2000) into vegetation types and then to roll up the vegetation into the 5 wetland classes recognized by the Canadian Wetlands Inventory (marsh, swamp, bog, fen, open water). This provided a way to update any changes that occurred in the wetland polygon after the initial inventory based on airphoto interpretation.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.SER_muster_point
Datasets.Description: The Muster Point feature class was created for the purposes of EMO with assistance from Halifax Transit. Designated bus stops were identified by Halifax Transit as gathering locations for transportation of people out of an area during an emergency evacuation. A number of meeting locations were also identified outside of Seniors Residential Complexes for the purposes of evacuation. All muster points for Seniors Residential Complexes are named after the Seniors Complex and all muster points at bus stops are names as the location of the bus stop.
Datasets.Summary: A Muster Point is a designated location for groups of people to meet during an emergency situation for the purposes of evacuation.

Datasets.Description: Proposed routes for the HRM Active Transportation Plan.
Datasets.Summary: The Active Transportation Plan was approved in principle on November 14th, 2006 by Halifax Regional Council. The Active Transportation Plan is a comprehensive document that provides policy direction for the development of an Active Transportation network within HRM. As well, technical guidelines have been created for the planning and design of the network. It is anticipated that promotion and education will be fundamental to the increase in the number of residents using active modes of transportation for their day-to-day activities.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.TRN_highway_distance_marker
Datasets.Description: Highway kilometre distance markers along the 100 series highways. All of the points in the provincial ( "one hundred" series highways) distance marker file were GPS'd (using differential correction) by a technician from our coordinate referencing section. We are confident the points meet or exceed NSTDB (1:10,000) specs at +/- 2.5 meters horizontal. The points were collected in phases shortly after TPW staff completed installation. As we become aware of further marker installation, we will collect these as well.

Subject to Change; Amendments to this data follow updates to Schedule A in the HRM Traffic Control Manual Supplement. Changes will require Council Approval.

Potential Open Data Candidate

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.TRN_hrm_trail
Datasets.Description:
Linear representation of trails, that are either owned, maintained, or of interest to HRM.

Available for internal and external use through Open Data Policy.

There is no formal process in place for updating this data. New trails will be added when details are forwarded to data custodian.As a result of the consolidation, there are many "NULL" values within the dataset.
Datasets.Summary: TRN_HRM_TRAIL is a consolidation of multiple trail sources (TPW_Trails, Trails_Verified, TRN_Trails, TRN_PPP) as of June 2012. Trails with a data source of TPW_Trail was collected in the Fall of 2009 using GPS. Trails with a data source of TRN_Trail are linear features classified as trails from the 10k May 1997 aerial photography.
Datasets.Purpose: TRN_HRM_TRAIL is a consolidation of multiple trail sources (TPW_Trails, Trails_Verified, TRN_Trails, TRN_PPP) as of June 2012. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.TRN_taz_travel_time
Datasets.Description: The dataset contains synthetic travel time estimates derived from the municipality’s travel demand model. The model simulates commuter behavior, land use, network conditions, and future scenario testing to predict travel times across different modes of transportation:- Driving → Fully Modeled   Travel times are generated by the Model, accounting for network congestion, road hierarchy, and trip distributions.- Transit → Fully Modeled   Includes bus frequency, stop locations, transfer penalties, and schedule-based wait times.- Walking & Cycling → Simple Calculation (Not Modeled)   Walking: 5 km/h assumed speed applied over network distance.   Cycling: 15 km/h assumed speed applied over network distance.   No congestion or intersection delays considered (basic GIS-based network travel time).This dataset captures both:- Baseline travel times (current conditions)- Future projections based on modeled scenariosEach update may include recalibrated model assumptions, new study areas, and updated land use conditions.
Datasets.Summary:
This dataset provides modeled travel times between Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZs) within the municipality for multiple travel modes including walking, cycling, driving (solo and carpool), and transit (bus, rail, and microtransit). Each record represents a directional travel relationship (origin TAZ → destination TAZ). The data supports commuter studies, accessibility analysis, transportation modeling, and policy evaluation.
The dataset captures synthetic (modeled) estimates that inform planning decisions and public engagement, such as the commuter guide story map.
Datasets.Purpose:
This dataset provides modeled travel times between Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZs) within the municipality for multiple travel modes including walking, cycling, driving (solo and carpool), and transit (bus, rail, and microtransit). Each record represents a directional travel relationship (origin TAZ → destination TAZ). The data supports commuter studies, accessibility analysis, transportation modeling, and policy evaluation.
The dataset captures synthetic (modeled) estimates that inform planning decisions and public engagement, such as the commuter guide story map.
Datasets.Tags: Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZ), Travel Time Modeling, Walking, Cycling, Driving, Transit, Travel Demand Model, Accessibility Studies, Commuter Analysis, Scenario Modeling, Policy Evaluation, Public Engagement, Active Transportation, Urban Mobility
Datasets.Credits:
"This dataset was developed by the municipality’s Transportation Planning Team. Travel times were modeled using a transportation demand model and manual calculations for specific travel modes.
For details on methodology, assumptions, or model updates, contact Adam Lanigan (lanigaa@halifax.ca)."
Datasets.UseConstraints: "This dataset is synthetic and does not represent real-world, observed travel times.Travel times are estimates based on assumptions, which may differ from actual conditions due to traffic congestion, weather, transit delays, construction, or behavioral changes.Driving and Transit travel times are fully modeled, while Walking and Cycling travel times were calculated using static speed assumptions.Not suitable for routing applications, operational planning, or emergency response.Users should refer to metadata for details on model assumptions, base years, and updates."
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: The dataset contains synthetic travel time estimates derived from the municipality’s travel demand m… | Tags: Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZ), Travel Time Modeling, Walking, Cycling, Driving, Transit, Travel Demand Model, Accessibility Studies, Commuter Analysis, Scenario Modeling, Policy Evaluation, Public Engagement, Active Transportation, Urban Mobility

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_2016_DA_AGE_INDV
Datasets.Description: This dataset is an export of the Statistics Canada 2016 Census of Population data for Age and Sex (98-400-X201600) release on May 3, 2017. The original data contains all population numbers for various individual ages, as well as, age ranges for all of Canada. Due to the size of the original dataset, this dataset only contains data for Halifax Regional Municipality and various individual ages per dissemination areas. For more informaiton on population for various age ranges and sex see the CEN_2016_DA_AGE_RANGE dataset
Datasets.Summary: This dataset was created for statistical purposes to offer additional information in regards to population and individual ages and sex.  The table can be used in conjunction with the CEN_dissemination_area_2016 feature class for spatial analysis using the DAUID.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_statscan_2021
Datasets.Description: This dataset is a compilation of Statistics Canada Dissemination Areas with associated population data from the 2021 Census. Population is rounded to the nearest 5
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of Statistics Canada 2021 Census Dissemination Area boundaries, along with population by individual age and sex at birth and gender.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of Statistics Canada 2021 Census Dissemination Area boundaries, along with population by individual age and sex at birth and gender.
Datasets.Tags: Statistics Canada, Census, Dissemination Area, Population, Age, Gender, 2021
Datasets.Credits: Statistics Canada 2021 Census Dissemination Area Boundary File, lda_000b21f_e.zip. Statistics Canada. Table 98-10-0023-01  Age (in single years), average age and median age and gender: Canada, provinces and territories, census divisions, census subdivisions and DA. Also several DA had data suppressed due to confidentiality requirements, values are NULL.
Datasets.UseConstraints: The original data contains all population numbers for various individual ages, as well as, age ranges for all of Canada. Due to the size of the original dataset, this dataset only contains data for Halifax Regional Municipality and various individual ages per dissemination areas.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_ArcHydro_10k
Datasets.Description: Collection of 10k hydrography datasets. The data model was defined by ESRI's ArcHydro.
Datasets.Summary: Used for stream network analysis functions such as upstream/downstream; and to manage relationships betweem watersheds, water bodies, networks, and monitoring stations. Not for standard HRM mapping. Please use the NAT_hydrography feature dataset instead as this contains more accurate data for the HRM. An exception to this use could be to map water bodies outside of HRM.
Datasets.Purpose: Used for stream network analysis functions such as upstream/downstream; and to manage relationships betweem watersheds, water bodies, networks, and monitoring stations. Not for standard HRM mapping. Please use the NAT_hydrography feature dataset instead as this contains more accurate data for the HRM. An exception to this use could be to map water bodies outside of HRM.
Datasets.UseConstraints: Provincial data. For internal HRM use only. Cannot be distributed to any clients other than those defined as Category 'A' in the GIS Data Dissemination Policy.
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: Collection of 10k hydrography datasets. The data model was defined by ESRI's ArcHydro.
